Introduction to the Catalog of Ancient and Modern Works, Part 1 of the Catalog of Ancient and Modern Works, 1 scroll. It is searched in various old catalogs.

Old Catalog of Scriptures, 1 scroll. It seems to be the catalog of scriptures seen in the Heavenly Pavilion by Liu Xiang of the Former Han Dynasty.

It is said to be hidden in the walls.
Or when the Qin king burned the books.
Those hidden by people.
Catalog of Buddhist Scriptures of the Han Dynasty, 1 scroll. It seems to be compiled by KÄÅ›yapa MÄtanga when he first translated the Sutra in Forty-two Sections during the time of Emperor Ming.
Zhu Shixing's Catalog of the Han Dynasty, 1 scroll. It is said that Zhu Shixing, a monk from Yecheng during the Cao Wei Dynasty,
In Luoyang, he lectured on the Sutra of the Way of Practice and wrote a record of it.
Later, he went to the Western Regions to seek scriptures.
He passed away there.

The Catalog of Various Scriptures in one fascicle. Right, during the Western Jin Wudi era, outside the Qingmen Gate in Chang'an, the Western Regions monk Zhu Fahu translated various scriptures and wrote a record of them.
The Catalog of Various Scriptures in one fascicle. Right, during the Yongjia era of the Western Jin Huai Emperor, the lay Buddhist Nie Daozhen received Fagu's calligraphy.
Later, he translated scriptures and wrote a record of them.
The Zhao Catalog in one fascicle. Right, it seems to be the various catalogs of the Two Zhao eras, with remote notes unknown to the surnames.
The Catalog of Various Scriptures in one fascicle. Right, during the Fu Qin era, the Å›ramaá¹‡a Shi Daoan compiled it.
The previous catalogs only listed the names of the scriptures.
As for the categories and eras,
they were omitted and not recorded.
Later readers could not understand the origins.
An then collected the titles and indicated their eras, classifying the new and old,
determining their authorship.
The scriptures have a basis.
From here it becomes clear.
Later, the various records will be enriched.
It is known that the lofty mind is uniquely enlightened.
It is sufficient to serve as a model for later generations.
The texts he compiled.
Seen in Seng You's catalog.
Two Qin catalogs in one scroll. Right, in the Hongshi years of the Later Qin, compiled by Shamen Shi Seng Rui of Chang'an.
Rui was An's disciple.
His spiritual abilities were comprehensive and clear, and his thoughts were outstanding.
He participated in translating in KumÄrajÄ«va's school and did much compilation.

The Tang Catalogue of SÅ«tras in five fascicles was compiled by Åšramaá¹‡a Xuanwan of Puguang Temple at the beginning of the Zhenguan era. It is quoted in the Neidian lu. The right Neidian lu quotes it as the Old Tang Catalogue.

Moreover, in the Changfang lu, it cites the Yishengsi zang lu, and in the Zhou lu, it cites the Zhenjisi lu, Yishanlu, Fashi lu, and the first five lÃ¼s. It only cites their names and does not mention the number of scrolls. There is also the Chen dynasty's Dachengsi zang lu in four scrolls, but it is unknown who compiled it. It seems to be a brief record of the scriptures in the temple's collection. Since the details are limited to the temple's name, it is not suitable for general use, so it is not included in the record of the lÃ¼s.
The Liang Dynasty's Record of the Collection of the Three Treasuries is fifteen scrolls. The preface briefly states:
I, You, am mediocre and shallow, yet I rely on the Dharma gate.
I revere the profound teachings and vow to spread the great transformation.
Every time at dawn and dusk, I recite and uphold them.
In autumn and summer, I lecture and explain them, never failing to let my mind roam in the Amra Grove and leap to Vulture Peak.
Thus, I drag my weak will and rest in the waves.
I investigate the sources and string together what I have heard.
It is called the Collection of Records of the Three Treasuries.
1. Compilation of the Causes and Conditions Record.
Second, a record of the names of the scriptures.
Third, a general preface to the sutras.
Fourth, a record of the biographies and origins.
If compiled, the original basis will be clearly shown. If the names of the scriptures are explained,
The years and months will not be lost. If the sutra prefaces are summarized,
The time of the great collection will be sufficient to verify the biographies.
If described, the style of the Yi people can be seen.
All of them have examined the inner scriptures and studied the external sources.
And so on.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

The compiler says:
The compilation principles of the ZÅu lÃ¹ are admirable.
If one carefully seeks, there are still discrepancies. For example, in the first volume, the Records of Different Versions of Sutras states:
The old sutras say TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyak-Saá¹ƒbuddha,
while the new sutras say Anuttara-Samyak-Saá¹ƒbodhi.
This is a mistake.
If compared with the old and new versions,
It should be said that the old scriptures say TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyak-saá¹ƒbuddha.
The new scriptures say TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyak-saá¹ƒbuddha.
The old scriptures say anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
The new scriptures say anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
The two meanings are completely different.
They cannot be mixed up.
Moreover, Dharmaraká¹£a and Zhu Faxing are the same person.
Dharmaraká¹£a means Dharma.
Raká¹£a means protector.
They are divided into two people.

Compared to the works of the masses, the errors and omissions are few. This is also a single flaw in the precious stone.

The Sui Dynasty's Record of the Three Treasures in Fifteen Volumes, with the title A Chronicle of the Three Treasures through the Dynasties, was compiled by Fei Changfang of Chengdu, a scholar who translated scriptures at Xingshan Temple in the seventeenth year of the Kaihuang era. The first part of the Chronicle of the Three Treasures through the Dynasties lists the years of the emperors of the Zhou and Qin dynasties.
From the tenth year of the Jiawu era of King Zhuang of Zhou,
to the Jiawu year of Zi Ying, the son of the First Emperor of Qin.

A total of twenty-six rulers and four hundred and eighty-one years.ğŸ”½The second part of the Chronicle of the Three Treasures through the Dynasties lists the years of the emperors of the Later Han Dynasty.
From the second year of the Yiwei era of Emperor Gao of the Former Han Dynasty,
to the jiazi year of the twenty-fourth year of the Jian'an era of Emperor Xian of the Later Han Dynasty.
A total of twenty-six rulers and four hundred and fifteen years.
The third part of the Chronicle of the Three Treasures through the Dynasties lists the years of the emperors of the Wei, Jin, Song, Qi, Liang, and Zhou dynasties.
From the first year of the Gengzi era of Emperor Wen of the Wei Dynasty,
to the dingsi year of the seventeenth year of the Kaihuang era of the Sui Dynasty.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
A total of forty rulers, with a reign of three hundred and seventy-eight years.
The fourth record of the Three Jewels through the ages, translated scriptures, Later Han.
To the right, from the tenth year of Emperor Ming's Yongping era, dingmao,
to the end of Emperor Xian's reign, spanning eleven rulers and one hundred and fifty-two years.
Twelve people, both Chinese and foreign, monks and laypeople, from ancient times to the present, have translated.
A total of three hundred and thirty-four scriptures and four hundred and sixteen volumes have been produced.
The fifth record of the Three Jewels through the ages, translated scriptures, Wei and Wu.
To the right, ten people, both monks and laypeople, from the two dynasties of Wei and Wu, have produced scriptures, precepts, and karmas, as well as old lost translations.
A total of three hundred and twelve scriptures in four hundred and eighty-two volumes.
The sixth record of the Three Jewels through the ages, translated scriptures, Western Jin.
To the right, thirteen people, both Chinese and foreign, monks and laypeople, from the Western Jin dynasty, along with previously lost translations of various scriptures and precepts.
A total of four hundred and fifty-one scriptures in seven hundred and seventeen volumes.
Record of the Three Treasures Throughout Successive Reigns, Part 7: Translated Scriptures, Eastern Jin.
To the right, during the Eastern Jin dynasty, twenty-seven people from China and India, monks and laypeople, produced scriptures and retranslated lost scriptures.
A total of 263 texts in 585 fascicles.

Produced scriptures, vinaya, treatises, and biographies.

Record 4: A Catalog of Important SÅ«tras and ÅšÄstras of the Past Dynasties, to be Read in Rotation, means that in reading and contemplating, the focus is on the important and extensive. The right one record is the ninth fascicle.ğŸ”½The fifth record of sÅ«tras from various dynasties with titles but missing texts means that by comprehensively examining the sÅ«tras and comparing the texts, there are those that were separately produced in different places but have not yet been fully clarified. Now the titles are separately listed for investigation.

The sixth record of commentaries written by monks and laypeople from various dynasties means that by commenting on the holy words to convey the incomprehensible, what was previously separate is not enough to fully explain. Now the titles are separately listed.

The seventh record, A Catalog of the Successive Generations' Scriptures and Branches, refers to the various scriptures that were produced separately in accordance with the times and customs, but which had not yet been widely circulated. The initial four-line verses should not be lightly deleted.

The eighth record, A Catalog of Suspicious and Fake Scriptures and Treatises Produced in Successive Generations, refers to the fact that the conditions for the true Dharma are distant, and ordinary people have not yet attained understanding. Following the customs, they have produced teachings that are mixed with the true essence. If this is not clearly indicated, then genuine and fake will be confused.
The ninth record, A Preface to the Catalog of Scriptures in Successive Generations, refers to the fact that the catalogs of scriptures produced in successive generations must recognize their origins.

The tenth record, A Catalog of the Miraculous Responses and Reverent Awe of Scriptures in Successive Generations, refers to the fact that when the scriptures were translated in China, there were auspicious signs and responses, which brought blessings and increased faith, causing the transmission to last for a long time.
The above six records are combined into the tenth scroll. If I wanted to be thorough, I fear it would be too much, so I have abbreviated it.
In the Catalog of Buddhist Works, Vinaya Master Xuan said:
I have been bathed in the Dharma stream for over fifty years.
My teachers are accomplished in teaching and their standards are wise.
Whenever I encounter a scripture, I personally read and study it.
As for the great catalog of the Sutra section, I am delighted and enlightened by many good things.
Regardless of whether they are true or false, I wish to hear about their differences.
Therefore, after the Wei and Jin dynasties, the translations flourished and steamed.
The compilation and discussion of catalogs are indeed not one.
Some use numbers to list,
some use names to seek,
some rely on the times,
some use the joint translations,
each records one corner,
striving to preserve what is seen.
These are all the ancient knowledge and understanding of the time, and the writing and editing are not very detailed.
It is not because of insufficient talent or insufficient wisdom.
Above, I gather the titles and take the texts such as the Biography of Monks to examine and determine them.
Then I refer to the catalogs of Zhizou and others.
Zhizou's catalog cites texts and meanings that can be observed.
However, the Mahayana and Hinayana are mixed together in the Tripiá¹­aka.
The collected notes are mixed with the biographies and records, confusing the sÅ«tras.
Examining from beginning to end, one cannot understand or decide.
The catalog of Fang came out later and includes what was heard before.
However, the three treasures are mixed with false and true, and the chaos is rampant.
How can we speak of the other catalogs?
Now, what I have compiled hopes to reform the previous shortcomings. The compiler says:
The one compiled by Xuan Gong.
The categories are clear and precise.
There is indeed something to be seen.
The style of the author is seen here.
However, there are a few errors and confusions.
It is still not perfect.
The matter of composition.
It is truly difficult.
Now, I will briefly outline several sections to clarify the errors.
I do not wish to point out right and wrong.
I truly want to distinguish right from wrong.
Like the Records of the Rise and Fall of the People.
The six sutras such as the new small sutra, etc., all say that they are the same as the large sutra, but this is not so.
Although the meaning and principles areé€š, according to the meeting, they are completely different, and they are said to be the same sutra.
One error.
The Bodhisattva Floating Practice Sutra and the Baoji Bodhisattva Sutra are both said to be translated by Zhu Faxing.
This is one sutra with two names.
Keeping its two versions.
Two errors.
The Sutra of the Samadhi of Vastly Manifesting the Way and the Sutra of the Dragon King Anavatapta are the same sutra with two different names.
Both versions are preserved.
This is the third mistake.
The Sutra of Sumeru's Treasury in two scrolls.
This was translated by Gao Qi Yeshe.
It is listed twice.
This is the fourth mistake.
The Treatise on the Compendium of the Great Vehicle translated by ParamÄrtha has a version in twelve scrolls.
There is also a version in fifteen scrolls.
Both versions are preserved.
This is the fifth mistake.
The Sutra of PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ is listed in both the Mahayana Catalog and the Collection of Biographies.
This is the sixth mistake.
Moreover, in the Catalog of Dividing the Vehicles and Entering the Canon,
the Sutra of the Profound Liberation is listed twice.

It is listed in the same case as the Sutra of the Bodhisattva's Entry into the Womb and also in the same case as the Sutra of the Profound Secret. This is the seventh mistake. The old Sutra of the Ten Wheels is listed as a single version, while the new Sutra of the Ten Wheels is listed as a retranslation. This is the eighth mistake. The Sutra on the Formation of the World is listed as a single version, while the Sutra of the Ages is listed as a retranslation. This is the ninth mistake. There are many such cases, but I cannot list them all.
The Shuyao Zhuan Du Lu lists the Xinli Ruxin Famen Jing, which is a branch of the Huayan Sutra, but is not found in the main text, along with the Du Shi Jianbi Jing and others.
To include it in the main text and not count it as a separate reading is the first mistake.
Among the various Prajnaparamita sutras, only the Mahaprajnaparamita Sutra is mentioned.
The other nine sutras such as the Pancavimatisahasrika Prajnaparamita Sutra are said to be redundant and rarely consulted. To cite the former to encompass the great meaning is exhausted in the Yuhua.
The later translation of the Mahaprajnaparamita Sutra states that the Buddha's teachings have sixteen assemblies and can be found in offerings, but are not commonly practiced.
I say this is not so.
How can one use one's own shallow wisdom as a commoner to block the ocean of Dharma?
People's natures are different and their preferences are varied.
How can one use one's own preference for brevity to make others share one's views?
The great Prajnaparamita sutra is widely read.
The Buddha predicted that it would be widely disseminated in the northeast.
Yet it is said to be difficult to use and not commonly practiced.
I am afraid this is not acceptable.
Moreover, the Small Prajnaparamita Sutra and the Large Prajnaparamita Sutra are completely different in terms of assemblies.
One is abolished, the other is promoted.
The second is unreasonable.
Although the SÅ«tra of Mount Sumeru's Treasury and so forth are separate parts of the Great Collection, they are not included in the main text and are not practiced.
The principle is considered inappropriate.
Moreover, the SÅ«tra of Mount Sumeru's Treasury is first included in the Great Collection and later separately promoted for circulation.
The earlier and later versions differ.
The third is unreasonable.
The SÅ«tra on Mountains and Tombs and so forth are included in the Long Collection.
The SÅ«tra on the Origin of the World is separately ordered to be recited.
The SÅ«tra on the Origin of the World and the SÅ«tra on Mountains and Tombs,
what is the difference in the Sanskrit text?
One is abolished, the other is promoted.
The fourth is unreasonable.
The SÅ«tra on Mindfulness of Breathing and the Great SÅ«tra on Mindfulness of Breathing are no different.
For what reason are both recited?
The fifth is unreasonable.
The Treatise on the Eighteen Schools and the Different Tenets of the Schools have no difference in the Sanskrit text.
For what reason are both ordered to be recited?
The sixth is unreasonable.

The Tripiá¹­aka is fully seen in the Records of Entering the Canon.

but be uniquely without it in the middle, creating contradictions itself?
